metadata.sermon_start_end: IT IS now exactly two decades since the beginning of what has generally been called the renewal at Grace Church. In 1975, I have been told many times, the choir almost outnumbered the congregation. Since that time, this parish, which in the nineteenth century was the most socially prominent [...] receiving from the depth of the Lord’s bounty “the unsearchable riches of Christ,” as Ephesians says — “the immeasurable riches of his grace which he lavished upon us” (Eph. 1:7-8; 2:7). God is at work. May we all enlist in his work as we find ourselves called, and may we continue in that calling with full and thankful hearts until the Day of the Lord. AMEN.

1_specific_bible_passage.findings: The sermon fails to focus on one specific pericope. It jumps between Amos 5, Amos 8, Romans, 2 Corinthians, and Matthew. It treats the Bible as a collection of keywords and 'bedrock' verses rather than recreating a specific text into a new, current word. The preacher admits to 'ranging afield'.
quotes: In another sense, though, I will be ranging afield somewhat.
I think of the bedrock as the verse from Romans...
I think of the verse, also from Romans...
I think of St. Paul’s two references, yet again from Romans...
1_specific_bible_passage.improvement_point: Select one specific passage from Amos and ask: 'What is in this passage that can be found nowhere else?' Avoid using other biblical books as a safety net for general dogmatic truths.

2_exegesis_original_context.findings: There is no evidence of Greek or Hebrew study, nor a deep dive into the religious history of Israel. The 'exposition' is reduced to a sociological parallel between Samaria and New York. The text's original meaning for the first readers is largely ignored in favor of its immediate political utility.
quotes: God saw the suburbs of Samaria with their swimming pools and their wine-tasting parties...
2_exegesis_original_context.improvement_point: Engage with the specific historical-theological context of the northern kingdom of Israel and the specific prophetic office of Amos, rather than modernizing the imagery immediately.

3_application_concrete_contemporary.findings: This is the sermon's strongest point. The application is highly concrete, referencing specific legislation (welfare reform), local geography (lower Broadway), and cultural artifacts (Calvin Klein ads). It avoids generalities by naming the specific 'zeitgeist' of the 1990s.
quotes: this week the Congress passed a sweeping bipartisan vote ending 'welfare as we know it'
Homeless people sleep on our very doorsteps.
I started boycotting Calvin Klein two years ago...
3_application_concrete_contemporary.improvement_point: Ensure the application flows from the text's unique point rather than from a general 'prophetic' mood applied to current events.

4_interwoveness_exposition_application.findings: The sermon is more of a topical lecture than an interwoven exposition. While it moves back and forth, the text is used as a springboard for the preacher's reflections on the congregation's history and current politics, rather than the hearer being 'expounded' by the text itself.
quotes: The prophet Amos was not popular at Grace Church when I first came here.
I think I do know something, however, about taking the temperature of American culture...
4_interwoveness_exposition_application.improvement_point: Let the movement of the biblical text dictate the movement of the sermon, drawing the hearer into the logic of the passage.

5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.findings: The categories of misery (social and moral), redemption (justification of the ungodly), and gratitude (the 'pro-active side') are present. However, they are often treated as 'bedrock' concepts rather than emerging from the Amos text. The psychological aspect of 'misery' is well-handled toward the end.
quotes: I know that I am self-willed and materialistic and neglectful of others.
He loves us too much to leave us the way we are...
5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.improvement_point: Ground the 'misery' specifically in the 'transgressions' Amos names, rather than general Pauline categories of 'the ungodly'.

6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.findings: The sermon addresses the 'two ways' primarily through the lens of temporal loss (society perishing) and the 'harsh spirit' of the land. It takes the hearer seriously as a responsible being, though the 'eternal' dimension is softened.
quotes: Seek good, and not evil, that you may live...
There is a mean spirit abroad in the land... a spirit of untrammeled self-interest.
6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.improvement_point: Sharpen the ultimate consequences of the 'two ways'—the possibility of being lost—without making it a mere political warning.

7_christocentric_grace.findings: Christ is the 'telos' of the sermon, but he is brought in as an external dogmatic requirement (Thesis 7) rather than being found in the 'garment' of the Amos text. The transition from Amos's social justice to Christ's poverty feels forced.
quotes: For you know the grace of our Lord Jesus Christ, that though he was rich, yet for your sake he became poor...
7_christocentric_grace.improvement_point: Show how the specific Word of God in Amos points to Christ, rather than pivoting to 2 Corinthians to 'fix' the Old Testament message.

8_depth_and_length.findings: At approximately 1950 words, the sermon meets the 20-minute requirement. It allows for the 'breadth' Miskotte demands, though much of that breadth is spent on congregational history rather than textual depth.
8_depth_and_length.improvement_point: Reallocate the time spent on 'valedictory' remarks and congregational history to deeper textual exposition.

overall_assessment.summary: The sermon falls short of Dekker’s ideal primarily because it lacks a singular focus on a specific Bible passage, instead functioning as a topical address on social justice and congregational identity. While it is exceptionally concrete in its application and respects the 20-minute threshold for depth, it treats the Bible as a source of general 'bedrock' truths rather than a living, specific Word. The exegesis is thin, replaced by sociological parallels.
strengths: Concrete application: The preacher avoids 'general truths' by naming specific cultural and political realities.
Human-oriented: It effectively addresses the 'misery' of the human condition (both rich and poor) in a psychological and spiritual sense.
Length: It respects the necessity of 'breadth' for theological depth.
weaknesses: Lack of textual specificity: It fails to identify what can be found in Amos 'nowhere else', relying on a mosaic of familiar verses.
Weak exegesis: The original context of Israel is neglected in favor of immediate modernization.
Dogmatic 'sleeping': Dogma (specifically Pauline justification) does not 'sleep' but is used to override the specific voice of the prophet Amos.
overall_assessment.final_judgment_according_to_dekker: This is an adequate speech for a congregational anniversary, but it is not a 'sermon' in the strict sense of Dekker’s theses. It fails the formal definition of 'exposition and application of a specific Bible passage' by being too broad and insufficiently grounded in the unique voice of the chosen text.
